- Mitchell v. Mitchell, 429 Mass. 681 (1.support_reasoning: The quoted opinion concerns Article 14 search-and-seizure protections and the validity of automobile exit orders and racial profiling. It does not address family law, custody, best-interests-of-the-child standards, material change in circumstances, or judicial discretion in modifying parenting plans or transportation arrangements. Accordingly, it does not support the modification principles or best-interests standard cited by the plaintiff.
- Mitchell v. Mitchell, 429 Mass. 681 (1.relevant_excerpt: I join in the opinion of the court and fully agree with its conclusion that, in the context of automobile exit orders, art. 14 of the Declaration of Rights of our State Constitution provides greater protection to Massachusetts citizens than the United States Constitution. … I write separately, however, to stress the dangers posed by unfettered police power to order individuals out of automobiles without any justification. The grant of such power is certainly, as the majority notes, “a clear invitation to discriminatory enforcement of the rule.”

- Sargent v. Sargent, 420 Mass. 836 (199.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns division and implementation of public employee retirement benefits via a QDRO in a divorce property division context. - Sargent v. Sargent, 420 Mass. 836 (199.relevant_excerpt: “In Early, supra, we established that the pension benefits of the former husband, who is a public employee, were properly included as marital property divisible under G. L. c. 208, §§ 1 et seq. (1994 ed.). … Although the QDRO as originally ordered by the Probate Court judge cannot fully be implemented by the board within the authority granted it under G. L. c. 32, the intent of the Probate Court judge … in dividing the marital assets under G. L. c. 208 should be effectuated to the extent permissible under c. 32….”

L. c. 210, § 3, proceedings on the basis of standing.”

- Fitzpatrick v. Fitzpatrick, 61 Mass. A.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns hazardous waste regulation, insolvency and closure trust funds, and the Department of Environmental Protection’s authority under G.L. c. 21C. It does not involve family law, parental relocation, child custody, best interests of the child, material change in circumstances, or a court’s discretion over parenting plans or transportation arrangements. Citing this case for those domestic relations propositions is therefore inaccurate and wholly inapposite.
- Fitzpatrick v. Fitzpatrick, 61 Mass. A.relevant_excerpt: “The governing statute grants DEP broad authority to regulate treatment, storage, and disposal facilities. General Laws c. 21C, § 4, sets out the powers and duties of the DEP. Among other things, ‘[t]he [DEP] shall be responsible for the supervision of the maintenance and operation of all facilities in order to ensure the public health, safety, welfare and the environment.’ … We therefore hold that the fund in question was intended to compensate third parties for damages arising from HCC’s storage of hazardous waste throughout its Springfield property.”

- Ramos v. Ramos, 28 Mass. App. Ct. 123.relevant_excerpt: “This dispute concerns an attempt by the plaintiff, USM Corp. (USM), to acquire a computer system for use in its business of manufacturing and selling shoe-making equipment. The defendant Arthur D. Little Systems, Inc. (ADLS), was organized in 1971 as a wholly owned subsidiary of the defendant Arthur D. Little, Inc. (ADL), for the purpose of developing, marketing, and installing ‘turnkey’ computer systems. USM and ADLS entered into a contract for such a system… Of the issues raised on appeal, we find it necessary to discuss at length only the contract and c. 93A claims.”

Smith and does not concern custody, parenting plans, transportation arrangements, or the best-interests-of-the-child standard. It is a commercial case about a credit union’s equitable security interest in a joint passbook account and the effect of a depositor’s death on that interest. It therefore does not establish or discuss (a) best interests of the child, (b) material change in circumstances for modification, or (c) judicial discretion over parenting plans or transportation, so it does not support the cited proposition.
- Smith v. Smith, 30 Mass. App. Ct. 171.relevant_excerpt: “We summarize the judge’s findings. Heffernan and William Dore opened a joint passbook savings account at the credit union in 1982… The issues, tried without jury, were, first, whether a valid security interest in favor of the credit union in the disputed portion of the account was created by the former joint owner in connection with the loan and, second, whether Heffernan obtained ownership of the disputed portion of the funds in the account by the right of survivorship.”
